articles.title: July '81
articles.summary: The article outlines a busy schedule for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) for July and August 1981, featuring numerous astronomical phenomena and club activities. July includes a New Moon, meteor showers, lunar and solar eclipses, and the anniversary of Skylab's reentry, alongside SJAA's annual picnic, board meetings, a Space Day event, and indoor/outdoor star parties. August continues with more indoor star parties, a general meeting, board meetings, and a star party at Fremont Peak.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: The author apologizes for the delayed July bulletin due to material hold-ups and personal error. The main announcement concerns the upcoming club picnic, offering free hamburgers and hot dogs (funded by a successful auction) and encouraging attendees to bring potluck dishes. This social event, held at Linda Vista Park in Cupertino, will include activities like officer installation, the presentation of the Dr. A.B. Gregory Award, and general recreation, with detailed directions provided for participants.

articles.title: Slide and Equipment Night
articles.summary: The June 20 Members Slide and Equipment Night was a successful event, drawing over 52 attendees. Members presented a diverse range of astrophotography slides and showcased various astronomical equipment, including telescopes and accessories. This popular "show and tell" format, which encourages member participation over guest speakers, is a staple for the SJAA and another such event is planned for late Fall.

articles.title: Elections
articles.summary: The article details the recent unanimous re-election of board members and officers for a club, highlighting the continuation of the existing leadership. It also features amusing excerpts from a board meeting, a letter to the editor disputing the common definition of summer versus astronomical solstices, and provides updates on visible and recently recovered comets.

articles.title: GREAT COMETS
articles.summary: The article discusses the historical "Great March Comet" of 1843, a Sungrazer known for its exceptionally long tail, with an expected return in 2356. It primarily details the extensive plans of amateur astronomers Gerry Rattley and Ernie Piini to observe the July 30-31, 1981 total solar eclipse from diverse locations, including Siberia and a high-altitude aircraft. Their expeditions involve specific scientific experiments and comprehensive travel itineraries across Russia and Hawaii.

articles.title: TOTAL SOLAR ECLIPSE - 31 JULY 1981
articles.summary: This document focuses on the Total Solar Eclipse of July 31, 1981, providing a map by Fred Espenak that illustrates the eclipse's path across the globe and marks various observation sites. The content also includes a humorous cartoon related to astronomy equipment manufacturers.

articles.title: The SJAA 12½-Inch Telescope
articles.summary: Jay Freeman details his successful completion of the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) long-stalled 12½-inch Newtonian telescope project, outlining its robust Dobson mounting, construction challenges, and specifications. The article also includes comprehensive observing reports from recent star parties, featuring numerous deep-sky object observations, and announces Denni Frerichs Medlock as the recipient of the Dr. A. B. Gregory Award for her significant contributions to amateur astronomy.

articles.title: NASA Administrator and Deputy Administrator Designated
articles.summary: James Beggs and Hans Mark have been designated as NASA's new Administrator and Deputy Administrator, respectively. During their Senate confirmation hearings, both men emphasized that a permanently manned Space Station should be the next primary objective for the U.S. space program.

articles.title: Soviets Build Modular Space Station
articles.summary: The Soviet Union initiated the formation of a permanent, manned space station on Friday, June 19th, with the link-up of the unmanned Salyut 6 and Cosmos 1267. This event combined the long-serving Salyut 6 base with a new module, forming a larger complex. NORAD reported the new orbital parameters of the Salyut-Cosmos 1267 combination shortly after the docking.

articles.title: ESA Successfully Launches Ariane 3
articles.summary: The European Space Agency (ESA) successfully launched its Ariane 3 expendable vehicle on Friday morning, June 19th, from Kourou, French Guyana. The rocket carried a dual payload consisting of the ESA weather satellite Meteosat 2 and the Indian experimental communications satellite Apple into orbit. This marked the third of four test flights for the Ariane program, following a previous failure with Ariane 2 and an initial success with Ariane 1.

articles.title: New members
articles.summary: This document provides a list of new members joining an organization, including their names, addresses, and phone numbers where available. It also lists contact information for one new bulletin subscriber.

articles.title: Saturday July 18, 1-10p.m.
articles.summary: This document advertises a "Multimedia Extravaganza" event on Saturday, July 18, from 1-10 p.m. at San Jose State, Morris Dailey. It features lectures by space experts like Stan Kent and Robert Truax, along with interactive exhibits such as Martian gravity simulators, hard vacuum demonstrations, astronaut food tasting, and solar telescopes. The event is sponsored by South Bay L-5 and several associated organizations, and is part of a broader 'Bay Area Space Week'.
